Proposed Grant 
Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste: District 
Capitals Water Supply Project

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
 
The currency of Timor-Leste is the United States dollar.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for the District Capitals Water Supply Project.1 
 
2.  The project will support the Government of Timor-Leste’s efforts to meet the Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs), particularly improved health of children under 5. The outputs of the 
project are (i) rehabilitation and expansion of water supply systems in Manatuto and Pante 
Macasar by the National Directorate for Water Supply and Sanitation (NDWSS), (ii) increased 
knowledge of efficient use of water and safe hygiene practices in project areas, (iii) sustainable 
operation and maintenance (O&M) of urban water systems by the district department for water 
supply and sanitation (DDWSS), (iv) sustainable secured water resources in Lehumo Lake, and 
(v) efficient management of the project by the Ministry of Infrastructure (MOI) and NDWSS.2  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Unsafe water and inadequate hygiene are two of the main causes of poor health in 
Timor-Leste and the primary causes of diarrhea. ―The two most significant causes of infant and 
child mortality in Timor-Leste—lower respiratory infection and diarrheal disease—are directly 
related to lack of water supply and poor sanitation and hygiene.‖3 The under-5 mortality rates in 
Manatuto and Oecusse districts are higher than the national average; this is attributed in part to 
the low percentage of their populations with access to safe drinking water.4 In Pante Macasar, 
the district capital of Oecusse, and in Manatuto, the dilapidated state of water supply assets and 
the lack of institutional capacity within DDWSS have resulted in unsafe and unreliable water 
supply systems.5 In Pante Macasar, 51% of households access water for only a few hours 
several times per week in both the wet and dry seasons. In Manatuto, 73% of households 
access water for only a few hours several times per week during the wet season; however, in 
the dry season, 59% report no access to water from the DDWSS system. With 37% of the 
population of Pante Macasar and 42% of Manatuto never having accessed water from the 
DDWSS system, the gap in service provision is considerable.6 The water provided by these 
systems is not safe for human consumption due to lack of continuous service, low system 
pressure, and poor maintenance of treatment and chlorination facilities. Residents of Manatuto 
and Pante Macasar currently boil and store water obtained from the system or shallow wells, but 
their storage methods lead to contamination and result in negative health impacts. 
 
4.  Poor hygiene is exacerbating the negative health impacts caused by lack of access to 
safe and reliable water supply. Eighty-eight percent of households in Pante Macasar and 98% in 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided project preparatory technical assistance (TA): ADB. 2010. Technical 
Assistance to Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for Preparing the Oecusse and Ermera Water Rehabilitation 
Project. Manila (TA 7649-TIM, for $700,000, approved on 17 November). Additional assistance was provided by 
the subproject Preparing Gender-Inclusive Community Participation for Oecusse and Ermera Water Rehabilitation 
Project  under  ADB.  2003.  Regional  Technical  Assistance  for  Promoting  Gender  Equality  and  Women’s 
Empowerment. Manila (RETA 6143, for $6.835 million, approved on 28 November). 
3  Office of the Prime Minister. 2011. Strategic Development Plan 2011–2030. Dili. 
4  National Statistics Directorate, Ministry of Finance. 2010. Timor-Leste Demographic and Health Survey 2009–
2010: Preliminary Report. Dili. 
5 Timor-Leste has been identified as fragile and conflict-affected, with weak governance and low capacity to provide 
basic infrastructure services. Source: ADB. 2011. Engagement in Fragile and Conflict-Affected Situations. Manila 
(September). 
6  Socioeconomic survey carried out by project preparatory consultants in June 2011 under the TA for Preparing the 
Oecusse and Ermera Water Rehabilitation Project. Available upon request.

2 
Manatuto treat water; boiling is the most common method. While 94% had soap or detergent in 
the house, actual hand-washing practice was not as high. Only 30% in both districts reported 
washing  their  hands  before  eating  (footnote  6). In Oecusse,  up  to  36%  of the  population 
practiced open defecation; in Manatuto, a town with higher population density, this was as low 
as  11%.  Consequently,  the  incidence  of  water-related  disease  is  higher  than  the  national 
average in both district capitals.7 In addition to the direct health impact on residents, lack of 
access to safe water contributes significantly to the workload of women because of the time 
spent managing the household water supply as well as caring for children affected by water-
related diseases (a burden generally assumed by women).8 By increasing access to water 
supply and safe hygiene practices, the project will improve the health of residents in Manatuto 
and Pante Macasar, particularly children, and will lessen the workload of women. 
 
5.  The government requested urgent assistance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
to rehabilitate Lehumo Lake to restore water resources in Ermera District. The existing lake 
embankments are in poor condition, do not retain the water, and have been eroded. This has 
lowered the lake’s water level, devastating the small-scale fishing relied upon by the community, 
and putting its wetland ecosystem in danger.9 The rehabilitation of  Lehumo Lake will restore 
water levels, and stop erosion along the banks of the lake, which has led to a significant loss of 
land that is vital to farming activities. These water resource management measures will improve 
a  key  livelihood  source  for  farming  and  fishing-reliant  communities,  which  are  among  the 
poorest in the country.  
 
6.  Timor-Leste’s Strategic Development Plan 2011–2030 targets the achievement of six 
goals by 2030, including (i) elimination of child mortality as a consequence of inadequate water 
supply, malnutrition, and lack of health care; and (ii) eradication of extreme poverty through 
―universal access to public services, ample job opportunities, and economic development in all 
regions.‖10 These goals are directly dependent on access to water supply and sanitation and 
improved water resources management, and are closely linked with the achievement of the 
MDGs.11 ADB’s  2011–2015  country  partnership  strategy  for  Timor-Leste  focuses  on  the 
provision of infrastructure, including urban water supply and sanitation.12 ADB, together with the 
Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), has been investing in urban water supply since 
2002. This project will continue ADB support to the urban water supply sector by rehabilitating 
and upgrading two urban water supply systems, ensuring their sustainable management, and 
facilitating the development of public–private partnerships (PPPs) for service provision, in line 
with the Timor-Leste PPP policy and the draft law developed with ADB technical assistance 
(TA) support.13  
7.  Since 2000, ADB has provided three project grants amounting to $11 million and two 
TAs amounting to $1.2 million to develop the water and sanitation sector in Timor-Leste. The 
                                                
7  National Statistics Directorate, Ministry of Finance. 2010. Timor-Leste Demographic and Health Survey 2009–
2010: Preliminary Report. Dili. 
8  ADB and United Nations Development Fund for Women. 2005. Country Gender Assessment. Dili. 
9  Bird Life International. 2007. Important Bird Areas in Timor-Leste: Key Sites for Conservation. Cambridge, identifies 
Lehumo Lake as one of the ―wetlands of national significance‖ for the conservation of endangered and near-
endangered birds in Timor-Leste. The report aimed to identify and conserve sites considered important for bird 
conservation according to internationally agreed standards. 
10 Office of the Prime Minister. 2010. From Conflict to Prosperity: Timor-Leste’s Strategic Development Plan 2011–
2030. Summary. Dili (April). 
11 Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, ADB, and United Nations Development Programme. 
2010. Asia-Pacific MDG Report 2010–2011. New York. 
12 ADB. 2011. Country Partnership Strategy: Timor Leste, 2011–2015. Manila. 
13 ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for the Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative Phase II. Manila (TA 7430-
REG).

3 
main  development  partners  in  the  sector  are  the  Australian  Agency  for  International 
Development,  JICA,  and  the  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development.14 Most 
support from these agencies is focused on rural areas. In Oecusse and Manatuto regions, the 
United States Agency for International Development with its District Water and Sanitation and 
Hygiene Program and Oxfam International have ongoing water supply and sanitation projects in 
rural communities, but the towns of Manatuto and Pante Macasar are considered urban areas 
and cannot receive assistance under these initiatives. This is the case for all district capitals in 
Timor-Leste, which are classified as urban irrespective of their size and population density. This 
project will build on previous urban water supply projects undertaken by ADB and JICA while 
coordinating with rural water supply projects funded by other agencies as needed. 
 
8.  Lessons from previous projects and evaluation15 in Timor-Leste highlight the need to  
(i) provide greater technical and managerial  support to agencies involved in water supply,  
(ii) increase the O&M capacity of water operators, (iii) support sector reforms to reintroduce 
tariffs  and  an  efficient  management  structure  for  NDWSS,  and  (iv)  ensure  appropriate 
institutional capacity is in place prior to increasing private sector involvement in water supply. 
This  project  incorporates  these  lessons  by  providing  institutional  support  to  NDWSS  in 
investment  and  asset  management  planning,  and  piloting  a  phased  PPP  approach  to 
rehabilitation and O&M. In addition, due to the current status of Timor-Leste as fragile and 
conflict-affected, the project includes elements of the 2007 ADB approach to engaging with 
weakly performing countries, such as a strong focus on extensive community involvement 
through  consultations,  strong  support  to  all  levels  of  government  agencies,  and  frequent 
monitoring to accommodate implementation adjustments as deemed necessary.16  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The project will ensure that more people have access to an improved supply of drinking 
water  in  Timor-Leste;  this  will  contribute  to  reducing  the  high  incidence  of  water-related 
diseases, particularly for children under 5. By the end of the project, NDWSS will provide safe 
and reliable water supply to the district capitals of Manatuto and Pante Macasar (outcome), and 
will lessen the workload of women. In addition, the Ermera community will properly manage 
their water resources. The project comprises a first step in the government’s plan to provide 24-
hour access to safe drinking water in all district capitals.  
 
C.  Outputs 
10.  Output  1.  NDWSS  rehabilitates  and  expands  Manatuto  and  Pante  Macasar  water 
supply systems, including (i) rehabilitation and improvement of the existing intakes of both 
systems  to  maximize  gravity-fed  sources;  (ii)  in  Pante  Macasar,  development  of  a  new 
groundwater source to be used during the dry season; (iii) rehabilitation and improvement of 
existing storage and treatment facilities; (iv) rehabilitation of existing distribution systems and 
construction of new water distribution systems in four aldeias of Pante Macasar and four sucos 
                                                
14 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan provides a list of other development partners active in the Timor-
Leste water and sanitation sector (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
15 ADB. 2004. Project Performance Audit Report: Water Supply and Sanitation Rehabilitation Projects Phase I and 
Phase II. Manila; ADB. Back to Office Reports: Dili Urban Water Supply Sector Project. Manila; ADB. 2011. 
Technical Assistance Completion Report: Dili Water Supply Performance Improvement Project. Manila; ADB. 2011. 
Country Partnership Strategy: Timor-Leste, 2011–2013. Manila; ADB. 2006. Timor-Leste: Community-Managed 
Water Supply and Sanitation. Manila; World Bank Public-Private Infrastructure Advisory Facility. 2009. Public–
Private Partnerships for Urban Water Utilities. A Review of Experience in Developing Countries. Washington, DC. 
16 ADB. 2007. Achieving Development Effectiveness in Weakly Performing Countries: The Asian Development 
Bank’s Approach to Engaging with Weakly Performing Countries. Manila.

4 
of Manatuto;17 and (v) installation of bulk and system water meters and replacement and/or 
installation of meters for all existing and new connections.  
11.  Output 2. Households in Manatuto and Pante Macasar have increased knowledge of 
efficient use of water resources and safe hygiene practices. The project will implement an 
intensive 6-month campaign for individuals and households, followed by a 6-month reinforcing 
campaign at multiple levels. The project will adapt the methodology developed in Manatuto and 
Oecusse  under  the  rural  water  program  to  the  urban  context.  The  training  will  cover  
(i) hand washing; (ii) proper handling and storage of drinking water; (iii) efficient use of water, 
including understanding of payment for water and metering; (iv) safe disposal of wastewater; 
and (v) use of latrines by all household members, including children.  
12.  Output 3. DDWSS utilizes sustainable O&M of water systems in district capitals. The 
project will pilot a PPP approach by packaging the rehabilitation of the systems with their O&M 
for 2 years, preparing bid documents and model contracts that focus on performance standards, 
preparing a manual for system O&M, and providing DDWSS personnel with on-the-job and 
external training to operate and maintain the system and to monitor contract implementation. 
During this period, the government, in line with its PPP policy and with support from the project 
team and ADB, will explore a long-term PPP arrangement for the O&M of urban water supply 
systems. In addition, local residents will be sponsored to receive vocational training on urban 
water supply and sanitation. 
13.  Output 4. Water resources in Lehumo Lake will be secured in a sustainable manner. To 
restore  water  resources  in  the  lake,  the  project  preparatory  TA  piloted  labor-intensive, 
community-led works to rehabilitate the lake, with more than 30% of the workers being women. 
The project will continue this approach and will (i) stop erosion through the use of gabions and 
the planting of trees, (ii) secure reasonable impermeability of the two embankments through a 
borehole-grouting technique, (iii) raise the embankments and secure them with concrete, and 
(iv) rehabilitate the broken spillway in the western embankment. 
14.  Output 5. MOI and the implementing agencies provide efficient project management 
and  monitoring  services.  The  project  will  provide  support  to  MOI;  NDWSS;  the  National 
Directorate  for  Roads,  Bridges,  and  Flood  Control  (NDRBFC);  and  the  communities  to 
supervise  project  implementation  and  PPP  contract  monitoring.  The  project  will  provide 
consulting  services  to  assist  NDWSS  in  preparing  a  preliminary  investment  plan  for  the 
rehabilitation and expansion of urban water supply systems for the remaining district capitals. 
The government and ADB can use this plan to make decisions regarding additional financing.  
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
 
15.  The project is estimated to cost $14.32 million, including taxes and duties of $0.20 
million. The total cost includes physical and price contingencies. The project investment plan is 
in Table 1. 
 
16.  The government has requested a grant not exceeding $11 million from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources to finance 77% of the project cost. The grant will cover civil works, materials, 
equipment, vehicles, project management, and capacity building.18 The government will finance 
taxes and duties and partly finance civil works and materials. The financing plan is in Table 2. 
 
                                                
17 The Timor-Leste administrative structure includes 13 districts, which are subdivided into 65 subdistricts, 442 sucos 
(villages), and 2,225 aldeias (hamlets). 
18 ADB may also finance transportation and insurance costs.

5

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  MOI  will  be  the  executing  agency.  NDWSS  will  be  the  implementing  agency  for 
components related to water supply and hygiene (outputs one, two, three, and five). NDRBFC 
will be the implementing agency for the restoration of Lehumo Lake in Ermera District (output 4). 
A national steering committee, comprising MOI, NDWSS, NDRBFC, the district administrators of 
Manatuto and Oecusse, the secretary of state for the Autonomous Region of Oecusse, and the 
Directorate  for  Aid  Effectiveness  (MOF),  will  guide  project  implementation.  A  project 
implementation unit (PIU) will be established to lead implementation of the outputs related to 
water supply and hygiene and the ongoing Dili Urban Water Supply Sector Project.19 The chief 
of District Water Supply and Sanitation of NDWSS and the chief of Dili Water Supply and 
Sanitation of NDWSS will lead the PIU, and the district manager of DDWSS of Manatuto and 
district manager of DDWSS of Oecusse will be members. Should the government adopt a new 
PPP law in 2011, a PPP unit will be formed to assist the PIU in monitoring implementation of 
project contracts. The project management unit, already established for ADB road projects, will 
support NDRBFC in tendering, contracting, and monitoring for the Lehumo Lake component. 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the 
project administration manual (PAM).20 
 
18.  ADB and the government may provide additional financing to expand the project to other 
district capitals. Grant financing will be used to prepare a district capitals investment plan to 
assess additional finance requirements. The potential to replicate the project’s water supply 
components will be discussed during the midterm review. 
                                                
19 ADB. 2007. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Grant to Democratic

approved on 18 December).

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
19.  The rehabilitated water supply systems in Manatuto and Pante Macasar are expected to 
provide efficient and reliable water service to their beneficiaries over a 20-year period. High 
hardness  and  biological  contamination  in  the  river  sources  for  both  Manatuto  and  Pante 
Macasar mean treatment is necessary before distribution and is included in the project. In Pante 
Macasar, the total water demand for the next 20 years is 2,701 cubic meters per day, which can 
be met through a combination of groundwater sources (production wells) in the dry season and 
surface water sources in the rainy season. In Manatuto, the demand for water will be 26.61 liters 
per second by 2031 for which the Laclo River has sufficient supply. In both district capitals, 
gravity-fed water supply systems are the preferred option when possible, as they are easier and 
cheaper to maintain over time than pumped systems. 
 
20.  In  Ermera,  community-led,  small-scale  civil  works  were  piloted  during  the  project 
preparatory TA to rehabilitate the lake and stop the erosion gully from increasing in size. The 
community demonstrated sufficient technical and management skills to undertake some of the

7 
remaining works, including installing gabions and planting trees. The contractors will conduct 
other major works such as grouting and building a concrete wall. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
21.  Economic analysis indicates demand for the project as the need for water by Manatuto 
and Pante Macasar residents in 2031 cannot be met by the current water supply systems. The 
estimated mean willingness to pay for usage is $2.29 per month in Manatuto and $1.71 per 
month  in Oecusse.  Usage tariffs  are  affordable  when  they  do  not  exceed  5%  of monthly 
household incomes with 13–14 cubic meters per month consumed. The monthly water cost to 
households, including for low-income families, remains below the affordability limit of 5% of 
household income at current tariffs. Benefits will arise from the project through economic and 
health benefits: cost of illness (24% of total annual benefits), savings in income loss (58% of 
total annual benefits), time savings (15% of total annual benefits), and treatment cost savings 
(3% of total annual benefits). Further benefits that could not be readily quantified include land 
value appreciation in the area and environmental improvement. The project has an economic 
internal rate of return (EIRR) of 17%, which is higher than the assumed 12% discount rate. This 
is  notwithstanding  the  fact  that  other  benefits  relating  to  the  environment  could  not  be 
realistically quantified and, therefore, have not been accounted for in the EIRRs. The EIRR 
remains above 12% for the following sensitivity tests: increase in capital cost by 10%, increase 
in operating cost by 10%, decrease in benefits by 10%, and a 2-year delay in implementation. 
 
22.  Financial analysis of project components was undertaken to determine the capacity of 
the NDWSS to cover project costs.21 The financial internal rate of return was calculated for 
revenue-generating components, namely the two water supply components and is 1.9% for the 
Manatuto water supply component and 1.8% for Pante Macasar. These figures are above the 
weighted average cost of capital of 0.59%. The two components are sensitive to revenue 
decreases and cost increases. Efforts must be made during project implementation to avoid 
such cost increases and the government must ensure tariff reintroduction to all customers. To 
help the district capitals achieve these targets, the project’s civil works contractor will provide 
O&M for 2 years and develop appropriate maintenance plans to ensure sustainability. 
 
C.  Governance 
23.  A financial management assessment concludes that the financial management capacity 
of  the  implementing  agencies  is  not  adequate  for  project  implementation.  Training  will  be 
provided  in  ADB  procedures  for  procurement,  disbursement,  project  management,  and 
accounting systems. Assistance from the PIU consultants will be provided to the implementing 
agencies for (i) budget preparation and oversight; (ii) preparation of an annual training program 
on financial management and skills upgrading; (iii) strengthening of the internal audit function; 
(iv)  establishment  of  data  safeguard  systems;  (v)  development  of  a  financial  policy  and 
procedures  manual  to  cover  financial  management,  reporting,  and  related  administrative 
activities; and (vi) provision of training in disbursement and project and financial management. 
 
24.  The good governance and anticorruption provisions include (i) enhancing construction 
quality control and the supervision of effective work; (ii) introducing a dual-signing system;  
(iii) periodically inspecting contractor activities related to fund withdrawals and settlements; and 
(iv) in consultation with relevant government ministries, updating the rules and regulations on 
                                                
21 The rehabilitation of Lehumo Lake in Ermera District will be fully financed by ADB and maintained thereafter by the 
communities.

8 
local  and  corporate  governance  and  anticorruption,  and  enhancing  transparency  of  the 
implementing agency operations. 
 
25.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with MOI, NDWSS, and NDRBFC. MOI, NDWSS, and NDRBFC have previous experience with 
ADB procurement; they will be supported by the PIU and MOI procurement advisers. Specific 
requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 20). 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
26.  The rehabilitated water supply systems will have the capacity to provide clean and 
potable water to about 30,500 people, including about 5,200 household connections. Safe, 
reliable, and affordable water is a basic need; fulfilling this need will directly reduce poverty in 
the two district capitals. Increasing access to safe water reduces poverty by (i) improving public 
health and reducing malnutrition, resulting in reduced expenditure on health and reduced work 
days lost from morbidity; and (ii) increasing time savings from water collection, storage, and 
boiling,  particularly  for  women  and  girls.  The  project  will  provide  (i)  access  to  metered 
household water connections, (ii) 24-hour per day water service, and (iii) awareness of safe 
hygiene practices to households in two district capitals of Manatuto and Pante Macasar. In 
Ermera, the project will reduce erosion in Lehumo Lake, restoring the lake to its previous 
condition. This will reinstate small-scale fishing relied upon by the surrounding communities and 
will open up the potential for ecotourism to develop—two livelihood opportunities for reducing 
poverty in Ermera. 
 
27.  Participation is a key element of the project’s approach to poverty reduction. The project 
will provide opportunities to form new and empower existing community-based organizations. A 
coordinating committee will be established in each district capital to bring together suco and 
aldeia chiefs, civil society representatives, water and sanitation office officials, and project team 
to  guide  the  project,  and  to  ensure  residents’  viewpoints  are  considered  during  project 
implementation and that they are involved in project monitoring. At least 30% of members of 
each coordinating committee will be women. Project investments will be available to all district 
capital households as the existing tariff scheme allows poor households to pay their connection 
fee over 1 year. In Ermera, a coordinating committee will also be established to guide activities 
surrounding the lake and a local nongovernment organization will be engaged to mobilize and 
train community labor to undertake small-scale civil works. 
 
28.  The project is categorized as gender equity theme. In Manatuto and Pante Macasar, the 
project will maximize benefits for women22 by (i) involving them in decision making through the 
coordinating  committees,  (ii)  encouraging  contractors  to  hire  them  for  labor-intensive 
construction  jobs,  and  (iii)  targeting  women  in  project  hygiene  awareness  campaigns  and 
vocational training. Women do the vast majority of water collection, storage, and treatment—the 
need for which will be reduced once households are connected to a safe, 24-hour per day water 
supply. In addition, women are the main caregivers of children, who are most affected by water-
related diseases. The physical and emotional burden of caring for sick children will be eased in 
project  areas.  In  Ermera,  the  project  will  (i)  involve  women  in  decision  making  through 
coordinating committees, and (ii) provide cash employment to women through community-led 
civil works during project implementation. The project includes measures to include gender 
quotas  in  labor-intensive  contracts,  ensure  equal  pay  for  men  and  women,  and  avoid 
construction camps. A gender action plan was prepared and will be implemented for the project. 
 
                                                
22 Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
E.  Safeguards 
29.  Environment. The project is categorized as environment category B, and an initial 
environmental  examination  with  a  detailed  environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  was 
prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  initial 
environmental examination concludes that no significant adverse environmental impacts are 
anticipated.23 The project’s significant environmental benefits will include reduced erosion in 
Ermera, and better water supply and water treatment facilities; reduced water losses from the 
currently inefficient water distribution systems; and improved hygiene and sanitary conditions in 
Manatuto and Pante Macasar. 
 
30.  In Manatuto and Pante Macasar, the project will introduce minor short-term negative 
environmental  disturbances  associated  with  construction,  which  will  be  mitigated  by  the 
operating procedures and monitoring plans detailed in the EMP. NDWSS will implement and 
monitor the EMP with the assistance of the PIU, which will be responsible for preconstruction 
and operation phase elements, and by the civil works contractors, which will be responsible for 
construction phase elements of the EMP. 
 
31.  The project will have positive environmental impacts on the Lehumo Lake area and will 
enhance the lake’s status among the ―wetlands of national significance‖ for the conservation of 
endangered and near-endangered birds in Timor-Leste.24 Basic environmental procedures will 
be  incorporated  in  the  contracts  of  individual  contractors  to  manage  minor  environmental 
disturbances  during  construction.  The  supervising  engineer  will  undertake  day-to-day 
implementation  and  compliance  with  ADB  and  government  environmental  and  safeguards 
regulations and policy for the Lehumo Lake output. 
 
32.  Social. The project is categorized as indigenous peoples category C and involuntary 
resettlement category C, so a resettlement plan was not prepared. In Pante Macasar, based on 
initial surveys and public consultations, no private land acquisition will be necessary for the 
development works. The proposed new location for the Santa Rosa storage and treatment 
facilities, which is just 100 meters off the existing site, is government-owned land and will be 
provided to the project at no cost. Private land acquisition is also not required for the Lehumo 
Lake  and  Manatuto  components.  Cultural  traditions  for  the  use  of  water  sources  will  be 
respected and are included in the consultation and participation plan. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
33.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.25 The integrated benefits and impacts of the 
project are expected to outweigh the costs. 
 
                                                
23 Construction-related impacts relate to dust generation and risk of erosion from excavation activities; and increased 
vibrations,  noise,  fumes,  and  traffic  disruption  during  construction  activities.  Good  engineering  design  and 
management plans will minimize these impacts as well as any impacts associated with operations. All effluent 
discharge will comply with national standards. Worker safety provisions will be included in contractors’ contracts. 
24 Bird Life International. 2007. Important Bird Areas in Timor-Leste: Key Sites for Conservation. Cambridge. 
25 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Lack of strong project coordination among  Extensive coordination support from the PIU consultants 
NDWSS, DDWSS, and beneficiaries  and frequent PIU onsite inspections and regular 
Lack of capacity in government agencies to  coordination meetings 
implement and coordinate the project 
Delays in the provision of counterpart funding  Covenanted assurances for timely provision of 
counterpart funding and PIU coordination with the 
executing and implementing agencies 
Lack of sufficient resources to NDWSS for  Support to develop an investment plan and asset 
O&M of urban water supply systems  management, including O&M provisions 
Provision of on-the-job training to DDWSS staff during 
the 2 years of O&M provided by the civil works 
contractors 
DDWSS = district department for water supply and sanitation, NDWSS = National Directorate for Water Supply and 
Sanitation, O&M = operation and maintenance, PIU = project implementation unit. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
34.  The government and MOI have assured ADB that implementation of the project will 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and grant documents. 
 
35.  The government and MOI have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which are set forth in the grant agreement. 
 
36.  Prior  to  effectiveness  of  the  grant  agreement,  the  government  and  MOI  will  have 
established the national steering committee and the PIU in accordance with the PAM. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
37.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board 
approve the grant not exceeding $11,000,000 to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste from 
ADB’s Special Funds resources for the District Capitals Water Supply Project, on terms and 
conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement 
presented to the Board. 
 
 
 
Ursula Schaefer-Preuss 
Vice-President 
 
31 August 2011

Activities with Milestones  Inputs 
1.   NDWSS rehabilitates and expands Manatuto and Pante Macasar water supply systems.   
1.1  Prepare detailed design and tender documents for Manatuto and Pante Macasar (Jan–Apr 2012)  ADB grant: 
1.2  Bid and award construction contracts for Manatuto and Pante Macasar (Apr–Jul 2012)  $11 million 
1.3  Implement consultation and participation plan in Manatuto and Pante Macasar (Jun–Aug 2012)  Government: 
1.4  Ensure contractors have the capacity to implement the EMP and GAP (Jul–Sep 2012)  $3.32 million 
1.5  Procure materials and equipment (by contractors) (Jul–Sep 2012)   
1.6  Rehabilitate Pante Macasar water supply system (Nov 2012–Nov 2014) by (a) improving Meokana,   
Oetulu, Tulebesi, and Tulumopu intakes and drilling one new production well; (b) constructing and   
rehabilitating tanks and treatment facilities; (c) installing transmission lines to Oesono, Sta Rosa, and   
Numbei and from well B to Samoro tank B; (d) installing distribution lines and testing pipe pressure;   
(e) constructing water house, pump house, and school toilets; and (f) installing water meters, and   
testing and commissioning the system.   
1.7  Construct Manatuto facilities (Dec 2012–Jun 2014) by (a) improving intake structure and source of   
We'e Teen Spring intake; (b) constructing tanks and treatment and pumping facilities; (c) installing   
transmission lines from We'e Teen Spring to Sau Tutun tanks and from Sau Tuntun tanks to Sede   
Souco Sau; (d) installing distribution lines; (e) constructing school and public toilets; and                      
(f) decommissioning Laclo river intake pipe, testing system pipe pressure, and commissioning the   
system.   
2.  Households in Manatuto and Pante Macasar have increased knowledge of efficient use of   
water resources and safe hygiene practices.   
2.1  Prepare tender documents and recruit NGOs to deliver awareness campaigns (Jan–Apr 2014)   
2.2  Recruit sanitarians and liaise with MOH for implementation of the hygiene program (Jan–Oct 2014)   
2.3  Train health promoters and establish a communication campaign (Apr–Oct 2014)   
2.4  Implement 6-month intensive awareness campaign for households (May 2014–May 2015)   
2.5  Implement follow-up multilevel campaign (Apr–Sep 2015)

Appendix 1     13 
Activities with Milestones  Inputs 
3.   Sustainable O&M of water systems practiced by DDWSS in district capitals   
3.1  Prepare water safety plans for Manatuto and Pante Macasar following WHO guidelines and conduct 
water quality tests according to plan schedules (Jan 2012-Apr 2014). 
3.2  Provide NDWSS and DDWSS with training and equipment to monitor O&M in Manatuto and Pante 
Macasar and manage O&M performance contracts (Apr 2014–Apr 2015) 
3.3  NDWSS reviews O&M and cost recovery procedures and participates in O&M workshops and 
institutional reform discussions for the urban water sector (Apr 2013–Mar 2015) 
3.4  Implement a socialization and communication campaign to system customers on metering, billing, and 
importance of financial and technical sustainability of the system (Jan 2014–Mar 2015) 
3.5  Develop billing system under DDWSS for Manatuto and Pante Macasar (Jan–Jun 2014)  
3.6  Private contractor that operates and maintains the Manatuto water supply system prepares O&M 
manuals in locally relevant language and provides on-the-job training (Jun 2014–May 2016) 
3.7  Private contractor that operates and maintains the Pante Macasar water supply system prepare O&M 
manuals in locally relevant language and provides on-the-job training (Jun 2014–May 2016) 
3.8  Provide technical support to MOI and NDWSS for the preparation of a business case and tender 
documents for an O&M management contract after project completion (Jun 2015–Dec 2015) 
3.9  Develop vocational training in water supply and sanitation construction techniques and train 18 people 
in Manatuto and 18 in Pante Macasar (Apr–Jun 2011) 
4.    Sustainably secured water resources in Lehumo Lake 
4.1  Contract NGO, organize socialization meetings, and set up coordinating committees (Jan–Mar 2015) 
4.2.  Organize community labor, ensuring at least 30% are women, and 30% are men or women from 
vulnerable households (Feb–Mar 2012) 
4.3  Rehabilitate embankments (Jan–Sep 2012) 
a.  Prepare tender documents and award civil contract (Jan–Apr 2012) 
b.  Raise embankment main and closure, reinforce them with concrete and grouting (Apr–Aug 2012) 
c.  Repair spillways (Sep 2012) 
4.4  Complete erosion control works (by communities) (Mar 2012–Apr 2014) 
a.  Place geotextile and construct a gabion wall 1–3 meters high in front of existing retention wall 
and 3–6 meters high in closure embalmment (Apr–Jun 2012) 
b.  Train 30 community members, of which at least 30% are women, in tree planting and erosion 
control and building of nurseries  (Mar–Jun 2012) 
c.  Fence erosion area and seedlings, and plant 15,000 trees (Jun 2012–Jun 2014) 
5.   Executing and implementing agencies provide efficient project management and monitoring 
services. 
5.1 Complete advance procurement and award of PIU and design and supervision contracts, and 
promptly contract individual consultants and NGOs (Sep–Dec 2011) 
5.2 Ensure project accounts are kept and managed appropriately and ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time) followed; submit an independent evaluation of project accounts 
to ADB 6 months after the end of the fiscal year (Jan 2012–Dec 2016) 
5.3 The executing and implementing agencies establish and participate in steering committee meetings 
and provide guidance to consultants; implementing agencies ensure representation from key 
stakeholder groups (of which at least 30% are women) and maintain regular meetings to discuss 
project progress and monitoring (Nov2011–Dec 2011) 
5.4 Tender and evaluate bids for civil works packages and award contracts (Jan–Jul 2012) 
5.5 Implement and monitor GAP, consultation and participation plan, and EMP including training 
contractors to ensure they follow their contractual agreements with regard to the GAP, the EMP, and 
other relevant ADB guidelines (Jan 2012–Jun 2016) 
5.6 The PIU and/or team leader prepares monthly report and provides copies to NDWSS director and key 
senior staff ensuring that data is disaggregated by sex, and undertakes socioeconomic survey 1 
month after physical completion of the project (Jan 2012–Dec 2016) 
5.7 Liaise with other government agencies and major stakeholders in the urban sector to ensure 
coordination and facilitate knowledge sharing (Jan 2012–Jun 2016) 
5.8 Supervise O&M contract and implement activities and training programs included in output 3 (Feb 
2012–Jun 2016) 
5.9 Support activities included in output 2 to increase knowledge of efficient use of water resources and 
safe hygiene practices (Nov 2011–Nov 2016) 
5.10 Prepare asset investment plan for remaining 10 district capitals (Mar 2012–Jun 2013) 
ADB  =  Asian  Development  Bank,  DDWSS  =  district  department  for  water  supply  and  sanitation,  EMP  = 
environmental management plan, GAP = gender action plan, MOH = Ministry of Health,  NDWSS = National 
Directorate  for  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation,  NGO  =  nongovernment  organization,  O&M  =  operation  and 
maintenance, PIU = project implementation unit, WHO = World Health Organization. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.
